FONT-VARIANT: normal">ITEM 1.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;BUSINESS</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">AMR Corporation (AMR Company) incorporated October 1982.&#160;&#160;Virtually AMR&#8217;s operations fall airline industry.&#160;&#160;AMR's principal subsidiary, American Airlines, Inc. (American), founded 1934.&#160;&#160;At end 2009, American provided scheduled jet service approximately 160 destinations North America, Caribbean, Latin America, Europe Asia.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">American, AMR Eagle Holding Corporation (AMR Eagle) AmericanConnection&#174; airline serve approximately 250 cities 40 countries with, average, 3,400 daily flights. The combined network fleet numbers approximately 900 aircraft.&#160;&#160;American Airlines founding member <font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">one</font>world&#174; Alliance, enables member airlines offer customers services benefits member airline provide individually. These services include broader route network, opportunities earn redeem frequent flyer miles combined <font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">one</font>world network airport lounges.&#160;&#160;Together, <font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">one</font>world members serve 700 destinations approximately 150 countries, 8,000 daily departures. American largest scheduled air freight carriers world, providing wide range freight mail services shippers system onboard American&#8217;s passenger fleet.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: -1.8pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">AMR Eagle, wholly-owned subsidiary AMR, owns regional airlines business "American Eagle&#8221; &#8211; American Eagle Airlines, Inc. Executive Airlines, Inc. (Executive) (collectively, American Eagle carriers).&#160;&#160;American contracts independently owned regional airline, business &#8220;AmericanConnection&#8221; (the AmericanConnection&#174; carrier). </font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">General&#160;&#160;&#160;</font>The Airline Deregulation Act 1978, amended, eliminated domestic economic regulation passenger freight transportation.&#160;&#160;However, Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) exercise regulatory authority air carriers.&#160;&#160;DOT maintains jurisdiction approval international codeshare agreements, international route authorities consumer protection competition matters, advertising, denied boarding compensation baggage liability.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">In April 2007, U.S. EU approved open skies air services agreement airlines U.S. EU member states open access other&#8217;s markets, freedom pricing unlimited rights fly U.S. airport EU including London&#8217;s Heathrow Airport.&#160;&#160;The provisions agreement effect March 30, 2008.&#160;&#160;Under agreement, U.S. EU airline authorized operate airports U.S. Heathrow.&#160;&#160;Notwithstanding open skies agreement, Heathrow slot-controlled airport.&#160;&#160;Only airlines American previously allowed provide service Heathrow.&#160;&#160;The agreement resulted Company facing increased competition serving Heathrow, Company lost market share.&#160;&#160;In addition, Company facing additional competition European markets.&#160;&#160;See Item 1A, Risk Factors, Note 11 consolidated financial statements additional information.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: -1.8pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">Security</font>&#160;&#160;&#160;In November 2001, Aviation Transportation Security Act (ATSA) enacted U.S.&#160;&#160;The ATSA created government agency, Transportation Security Administration (TSA), part Department Homeland Security responsible aviation security.&#160;&#160;The ATSA mandates TSA provide screening passengers property, including U.S. mail, cargo, carry-on checked baggage, articles carried aboard passenger aircraft. The ATSA security flight decks aircraft requires federal air marshals present flights.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: -1.8pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Effective February 1, 2002, ATSA imposed $2.50 enplanement security service fee, collected air carriers submitted government pay enhanced security measures. Additionally, air carriers annually required submit government amount equal air carriers paid screening passengers property 2000.&#160;&#160;In recent years, government sought increase fees spending proposals Department Homeland Security. period commences.&#160;&#160;During period (or after), Presidential Emergency Board (PEB) established, examines parties&#8217; positions recommends solution.&#160;&#160;The PEB process lasts 30 days &#8220;cooling off&#8221; period 30 days.&#160;&#160;At end &#8220;cooling off&#8221; period, agreement reached action Congress, labor organization exercise &#8220;self-help,&#8221; strike, airline resort &#8220;self-help,&#8221; TEXT-DECORATION: underline">Ground Properties</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: -1.8pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">The Company leases built leasehold improvements leased property: airport terminal facilities U.S. overseas; training facilities Fort Worth, Texas; principal overhaul maintenance bases Tulsa International Airport (Tulsa, Oklahoma), Kansas City International Airport (Kansas City, Missouri) Alliance Airport (Fort Worth, Texas); regional reservation offices; local ticket administration offices system.&#160;&#160;In October 2009, AMR announced planned closure Kansas City overhaul maintenance base create <font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">more flexible, cost-efficient operation improves flow takes account long-term impact recession travel, deep capacity cuts industry, decline maintenance, repair overhaul (MRO) business, Company&#8217;s network fleet size. </font>The Company owns headquarters building Fort Worth, Texas, mortgage loan payable.&#160;&#160;American entered agreements Tulsa Municipal Airport Trust; Alliance Airport Authority, Fort Worth, Texas; New York City Industrial Development Agency; Dallas/Fort Worth, Chicago O'Hare, Newark, San Juan, Los Angeles airport authorities provide funds constructing, improving modifying facilities acquiring equipment leased Company.&#160;&#160;The Company public airports flight operations lease arrangements municipalities governmental agencies owning controlling leases ground equipment facilities.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: -1.8pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">For information estimated lives residual values owned ground properties, lease terms amortization relating ground properties capital leases, acquisitions ground properties, Notes 1 5 consolidated financial statements.</font></div> <br> <div id="PGBRK" style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"> <div id="FTR"> <div id="GLFTR" style="WIDTH: 100%" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 8pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160; </font></div></div> <div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: always"> <div style="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: center"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 8pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160; </font></div> <div style="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: center"> <hr style="COLOR: black" noshade size="2"></div></div> <div id="HDR"> <div id="GLHDR" style="WIDTH: 100%" align="right"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 8pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160; </font></div></div></div> <br> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: -1.8pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">ITEM 3.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;LEGAL PROCEEDINGS</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: -1.8pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Between April 3, 2003 June 5, 2003, lawsuits filed travel agents, opted prior class action (now dismissed) pursue claims individually American, airline defendants, case, airline defendants Orbitz LLC.&#160; The cases, Tam Travel et. al., v. Delta Air Lines et. al., United States District Court Northern District California, San Francisco (51 individual agencies), Paula Fausky d/b/a Timeless Travel v. American Airlines, et. al, United States District Court Northern District Ohio, Eastern Division (29 agencies) Swope Travel al. v. Orbitz et. al. United States District Court Eastern District Texas, Beaumont Division (71 agencies) consolidated pre-trial purposes United States District Court Northern District Ohio, Eastern Division.&#160; Collectively, lawsuits seek damages injunctive relief alleging airline defendants Orbitz LLC: (i) conspired prevent travel agents acting effective competitors distribution airline tickets passengers violation Section 1 Sherman Act;&#160; (ii) conspired monopolize distribution common carrier air travel airports United States violation Section 2 Sherman Act; (iii) 1995 present, airline defendants conspired reduce commissions paid U.S.-based travel agents violation Section 1 Sherman Act.&#160; On September 23, 2005, Fausky plaintiffs dismissed claims prejudice. &#160;On September 14, 2006, court dismissed prejudice 28 Swope plaintiffs.&#160;&#160;On October 29, 2007, court dismissed actions.&#160;&#160;The Tam plaintiffs appealed court&#8217;s decision, October 2, 2009, Sixth Circuit Court Appeals affirmed lower court decision.&#160;&#160;The Swope plaintiffs moved case remanded Eastern District Texas. &#160;American continues vigorously defend lawsuits.&#160; A final adverse court decision awarding substantial money damages placing material restrictions Company&#8217;s distribution practices material adverse impact Company.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">On July 12, 2004, consolidated class action complaint subsequently amended November 30, 2004, filed American Association Professional Flight Attendants (APFA), union represents American&#8217;s flight attendants (Ann M. Marcoux, al., v. American Airlines Inc., al. United States District Court Eastern District New York). While class certified, lawsuit seeks behalf American&#8217;s flight attendants subclasses set obtain damages allegedly resulting April 2003 Collective Bargaining Agreement referred Restructuring Participation Agreement (RPA). The RPA labor agreements American successfully reached unions order avoid filing bankruptcy 2003.&#160;&#160;In related case (Sherry Cooper, al. v. TWA Airlines, LLC, al., United States District Court Eastern District New York), court denied preliminary injunction implementation RPA September 30, 2003. The Marcoux suit alleges claims APFA American relating RPA ratification vote RPA individual APFA members, including: violation Labor Management Reporting Disclosure Act (LMRDA) APFA&#8217;s Constitution By-laws, violation APFA duty fair representation members, violation American provisions Railway Labor Act (RLA) improper coercion flight attendants voting changing vote ratification, violations Racketeer Influenced Corrupt Organizations&#160;Act 1970 (RICO). On March 28, 2006, district court dismissed state law claims American, LMRDA claims APFA, claimed violations RICO.&#160;&#160;On July 22, 2008, district court granted summary judgment American APFA remaining claimed violations RLA duty fair representation American APFA (as LMRDA claim claim APFA breach constitution).&#160;&#160;A notice appeal filed behalf purported class flight attendants. On September 21, 2009, U.S. Court Appeals Second Circuit affirmed district court&#8217;s decision favor American APFA.&#160;&#160;The plaintiffs seeking review U.S. Supreme Court decision Court Appeals.&#160;&#160;Although Company believes case merit American APFA vigorously defended lawsuit, final adverse court decision invalidating RPA awarding substantial money damages material adverse impact Company.</font> <br> <div id="PGBRK" style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"> <div id="FTR">&#160;</div> <div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: always"> <div style="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: center"> <hr style="COLOR: black" noshade size="2"></div></div> <div id="HDR">&#160;</div></div> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">On February 14, 2006, Antitrust Division United States Department Justice (DOJ) served Company grand jury subpoena part ongoing investigation criminal violations antitrust laws domestic foreign air cargo carriers. traffic decreased 6.7 percent 8.3 billion revenue passenger miles (RPMs), capacity decreased 8.2 percent 11.6 billion ASMs, resulting 1.2 point increase passenger load factor 71.4 percent.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: -1.8pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Other revenues increased 5.4 percent, $118 million, $2.3 billion due increases passenger service charges instituted year 2008.</font> <br> <div id="PGBRK" style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"> <div id="FTR">&#160;</div> <div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: always"> <div style="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: center"> <hr style="COLOR: black" noshade size="2"></div></div> <div id="HDR">&#160;</div></div> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold; FONT-STYLE: italic">2008 Compared 2007&#160;&#160;&#160;</font> The Company&#8217;s revenues increased approximately $831 million, 3.6 percent, $23.8 billion 2008 compared 2007. American&#8217;s passenger revenues increased 3.3 percent, $583 million, significant capacity (ASM) decrease 3.8 percent.&#160;&#160;American&#8217;s passenger load factor decreased approximately point 80.6 percent passenger revenue yield passenger mile increased 8.6 percent 13.84 cents.&#160;&#160;This resulted increase passenger revenue seat mile (RASM) 7.3 percent 11.15 cents. In 2008, American derived approximately 60 percent passenger revenues domestic operations approximately 40 percent international operations (flights serving international destinations).&#160;&#160;Following additional information American&#8217;s domestic international RASM capacity:</font></div> <div align="left"> <table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br> <div id="PGBRK" style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"> <div id="FTR">&#160;</div> <div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: always"> <div style="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: center"> <hr style="COLOR: black" noshade size="2"></div></div> <div id="HDR">&#160;</div></div></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt">&#160;</div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">Interest</font>&#160;&#160;&#160;The Company&#8217;s earnings affected interest rates due impact interest income cash short-term investments, interest expense variable-rate debt instruments.&#160;&#160;The Company&#8217;s largest exposure respect variable rate debt London Interbank Offered Rate (LIBOR). The Company variable rate debt instruments representing approximately 23 percent 28 percent total long-term debt December 31, 2009 2008, respectively.&#160;&#160;If Company&#8217;s interest rates average 10 percent 2010 December 31, 2009, Company&#8217;s interest expense increase approximately $8 million interest income cash short-term investments increase approximately $1 million.&#160;&#160;In comparison, December 31, 2008, Company estimated interest rates averaged 10 percent 2009 December 31, 2008, Company&#8217;s interest expense increased approximately $13 million interest income cash short-term investments increased approximately $7 million.&#160;&#160;These amounts determined impact hypothetical interest rates Company&#8217;s variable rate long-term debt cash short-term investment balances December 31, 2009 2008.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Market risk fixed rate long-term debt estimated potential increase fair resulting hypothetical 10 percent decrease interest rates amounts approximately $316 million $297 million December 31, 2009 2008, respectively. FONT-WEIGHT: bold">Measurement Asset Impairments&#160;&#160;&#160;</font>The Company records impairment charges long-lived assets operations events circumstances assets impaired. (ii) estimated future cash flows expected generated asset, based additional assumptions asset utilization, length service asset Company&#8217;s operations estimated salvage values.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-ALIGN: center"> <hr style="COLOR: black" noshade size="2"></div></div> <div id="HDR"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times roman; TEXT-DECORATION: underline">6.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;Indebtedness (Continued)</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Maturities long-term debt (including sinking fund requirements) years are: 2010 - $1.0 billion; 2011 - $2.3 billion; 2012 - $1.7 billion; 2013 - $957 million, 2014 - $1.4 billion.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">As December 31, 2009, AMR issued guarantees covering approximately $1.6 billion American&#8217;s tax-exempt bond debt (and interest thereon) $450 million American&#8217;s secured debt (and interest thereon).&#160;&#160;American issued guarantees covering approximately $885 million AMR&#8217;s unsecured debt (and interest thereon).&#160;&#160;In addition, December 31, 2009, AMR American issued guarantees covering approximately $262 million AMR Eagle&#8217;s secured debt (and interest thereon) AMR issued additional guarantees covering $2.0 billion AMR Eagle&#8217;s secured debt (and interest thereon).&#160;&#160;AMR guarantees $186 million American&#8217;s leases Super ATR aircraft, subleased AMR Eagle.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: -1.8pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">In quarter 2009, AMR retired, purchasing cash $318 million principal amount 4.50 Notes.&#160;&#160;Virtually holders 4.50 Notes exercised elective put rights Company purchased retired notes price equal 100 percent principal amount.&#160;&#160;Under terms 4.50 Notes, Company option pay purchase price cash, stock, combination cash stock, Company elected pay 4.50 Notes solely cash.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">On July 7, 2009, American closed $520 million Pass Through Trust Certificates (the Certificates) financing covering Boeing 777-200ER aircraft owned American 16 American&#8217;s Boeing 737-800 deliveries.&#160;&#160;Equipment notes underlying Certificates bear interest 10.375 percent annum principal interest notes payable semi-annual installments balloon payment maturity 2019.&#160;&#160;Approximately $314 million proceeds sale Certificates received American December 31, 2009 exchange equipment notes secured Boeing 777-200ER aircraft delivery financing Boeing 737-800 aircraft.&#160;&#160;The remainder proceeds held escrow benefit holders Certificates.&#160;&#160;When American finances remaining Boeing 737-800 aircraft arrangement, allocable portion proceeds released American exchange equipment notes secured individual aircraft debt recorded American.&#160;&#160;American expects escrowed proceeds Certificates finance Boeing 737-800 aircraft scheduled delivered American February 2010 April 2010, American elect financing 37 Boeing 737-800 aircraft deliveries scheduled delivery February 2010 October 2010.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">In addition, party holding collateral American cover interest distributable Certificates prior remaining Boeing 737-800 aircraft delivered related equipment notes issued.&#160;&#160;Any collateral remitted holders interest returned Company.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify">&#160;</div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Once fully issued, American hold variable interests pass trusts created Certificates, expected primary beneficiary trust.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">On July 31, 2009, American closed $276 million private placement offering senior secured notes due 2016 (2009-2 Secured Notes), priced par yield 13 percent.&#160;&#160;The purpose offering refinance, part, outstanding $401 million principal amount Company&#8217;s 1999-1 enhanced equipment trust certificates (1999 EETC).&#160;&#160;Following payment 1999 EETC maturity October 15, 2009, twelve 15 aircraft previously secured 1999 EETC pledged secure 2009-2 Secured Notes, cash collateral released Company.&#160;&#160;The aircraft pledged secure 2009 Loan Facility referred below.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">On September&#160;16, 2009, American entered arrangement Citibank paid American $1.0&#160;billion order pre-purchase AAdvantage Miles (the Advance Purchase Miles) American&#8217;s AAdvantage frequent flier loyalty program (the Advance Purchase).</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">To effect Advance Purchase, American Citibank entered Amended Restated AAdvantage Participation Agreement (as amended restated, Amended Participation Agreement). Under Amended Participation Agreement, American agreed apply equal monthly installments, year period beginning January&#160;1, 2012, Advance Purchase Miles Citibank cardholders&#8217; AAdvantage accounts.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <div id="PGBRK" style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"> <div id="FTR">&#160;</div> <div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: always"> <div style="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: center"> <hr style="COLOR: black" noshade size="2"></div></div> <div id="HDR">&#160;</div></div></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times roman; TEXT-DECORATION: underline">6.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;Indebtedness (Continued)</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Pursuant Advance Purchase, Citibank granted first-priority lien American&#8217;s AAdvantage program assets, lien American&#8217;s Heathrow Narita routes slots subordinated subsequent lien.&#160;&#160;Commencing December 31, 2011, American repurchase, premium penalty, Advance Purchase Miles posted Citibank cardholders&#8217; accounts. TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">Fuel Price Risk Management&#160;&#160;&#160;</font>As part Company's risk management program, variety financial instruments, primarily heating oil option collar contracts, cash flow hedges mitigate commodity price risk.&#160;&#160;The Company hold issue derivative financial instruments trading purposes.&#160;&#160;As December 31, 2009, Company fuel derivative contracts outstanding covering 20 million barrels jet fuel settled 24 months.&#160;&#160;A deterioration Company&#8217;s liquidity position negatively affect Company&#8217;s ability hedge fuel future.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">In accordance U.S. GAAP, Company assesses, inception hedge ongoing basis, derivatives hedging transactions highly effective offsetting cash flows hedged items.&#160;&#160;Derivatives meet requirements granted special hedge accounting treatment, Company&#8217;s hedges generally meet requirements.&#160;&#160;Accordingly, Company&#8217;s fuel derivative contracts accounted cash flow hedges, fair Company&#8217;s hedging contracts recorded Current Assets Current Liabilities accompanying consolidated balance sheets underlying jet fuel purchased. The Company determines ineffective portion fuel hedge contracts comparing cumulative change total fuel hedge contract, group fuel hedge contracts, cumulative change hypothetical jet fuel hedge.&#160;&#160;If total cumulative change fuel hedge contract offsets total cumulative change hypothetical jet fuel hedge, difference considered ineffective immediately recognized component Aircraft fuel expense.&#160;&#160;Effective gains losses fuel hedging contracts deferred Accumulated comprehensive income (loss) recognized earnings component Aircraft fuel expense underlying jet fuel hedged used.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Ineffectiveness inherent hedging jet fuel derivative positions based crude oil crude oil related commodities.&#160;&#160;In assessing effectiveness, Company regression model determine correlation change prices commodities hedge jet fuel (e.g., NYMEX Heating oil) change price jet fuel.&#160;&#160;The Company monitors actual dollar offset hedges&#8217; market values compared hypothetical jet fuel hedges.&#160;&#160;The fuel hedge contracts generally deemed &#8220;highly effective&#8221; R-squared greater 80 percent dollar offset correlation 80 percent 125 percent.&#160;&#160;The Company discontinues hedge accounting prospectively determines derivative longer expected highly effective hedge decides discontinue hedging relationship.&#160;&#160;Subsequently, fair derivatives marked market earnings period change.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">For years ended December 31, 2009, 2008 2007, Company recognized net gains (losses) approximately ($651) million, $380&#160;&#160;million $239 million, respectively, component Aircraft fuel expense accompanying consolidated statements operations related fuel hedging agreements, including ineffective portion hedges.&#160;&#160;The fair Company&#8217;s fuel hedging agreements December 31, 2009 2008, representing amount Company receive (pay) termination agreements, totaled $57 million ($450) million, respectively, excludes payable years related contracts settled December year.&#160;&#160;As December 31, 2009, Company estimates twelve months reclassify Accumulated comprehensive loss earnings approximately $74 million net losses (based prices December 31, 2009) related fuel derivative hedges, including losses terminated contracts bankrupt counterparty 2008.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; In January 2010, contracts settled net impact Company&#8217;s financial statements.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <br> <div id="PGBRK" style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"> <div id="FTR">&#160;</div> <div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: always"> <div style="WIDTH: 100%; The 103-12 investment trust valued net asset determined issuer end month based aggregate fair trust assets liabilities, divided number units outstanding. Investments segregated funds carried net asset value, based fair market underlying asset.&#160;&#160;&#160;No valuation techniques inputs occurred period.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; Accordingly, Article 8.2 Purchase Agreement deleted entirety replaced following:</font></div></td></tr></table></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 63pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#8220;8.2&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;(a)&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;Except set Agreement, Basic Aircraft Price subject escalation accordance formula set Schedule (the &#8220;Economic Adjustment Formula&#8221;). FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">(iii) provide Bombardier, drawings forwarded Buyer, language translations interior exterior Aircraft labels.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div> <table align="center" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" id="hangingindent" width="100%" style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt;
